instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-00875: What is 820-00875? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1708: What is A1708? A1708 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2017, 2016 with EMC 3164, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00840, 820-00875..
definitions.BKLT_SD: What is BKLT_SD? BKLT_SD is a pin of the LED driver that goes to the voltage divider that feeds the gate of the transistor that sits between PPBUS_G3H and the backlight circuit. The LED driver will short this pin to ground when backlight circuit is ready to turn on. Prerequisites are 1) it is told to turn on via enable signal, the screen has communicated with the LED driver 2) current sensing circuit is working 3) does not detect an over-current situation such as the backlight power rail being shorted to ground.
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - No backlight - A stupid noob error
threads.message:
Hey everybody

Nice to be here ))

I made a very stupid error. A customer asked me to replace a cracked screen on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> EMC2978 Macbook pro.

So I did )) forgetting to disconnect the battery <SIGNAL>O_O</SIGNAL>

And now no backlight on the machine, and i'm sure it works as we can see the image. Same thing with old cracked screen. As I thought the new screen might be wrong or faulty.

Here some voltage details :

On disassabled board / no screen connected :

Power consumption at wall :
7.1 volts / 0.085 amps

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0_BKLT</SIGNAL> / <RESISTOR>R8444</RESISTOR> - 5.11V
<CHIP>U8400</CHIP> pin 17,18 - 0V (<CAPACITOR>C8442</CAPACITOR> is absent)
<CHIP>U8400</CHIP> pin 5 - 5V
<CAPACITOR>C8473</CAPACITOR> - 0V
<TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR> - pins 3,4 - 13V, pins 1,2,5,6 - 0V

Hope i measured right components, kindly let me know if you need more info.

Best regards

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - No backlight - A stupid noob error
threads.message:
First of all, welcome to the forum.

Stop to diagnose backlight problems (nor video related), without LCD connected.

USB-C ports should switch to 20V, not 7V.
Do you get any voltage at L7210/20?

nope 0V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - No backlight - A stupid noob error
threads.message:
Then the board doesn't even boot now.
Turning on and booting, is not the same thing.

Now keep the LCD disconnected, as any other device.
Only need the charger, untill get correct CPU core voltage.
Do you get L7370 and L7730 voltage?

Check for short at <CAPACITOR>C8441</CAPACITOR>; if pin 5 has 5V, pin 18 should be the same.
If not, replace <RESISTOR>R8445</RESISTOR>.

BTW, write directly into Reply box, instead of clicking Reply button.
Not a real reason to quote an entire post, visible few centimeters above.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - No backlight - A stupid noob error
threads.message:
okok noted )

L7370 - 1.122V on one side and 1.059V on the other
L7730 - 1.06V on both

<CAPACITOR>C8441</CAPACITOR> - 0V on both sides - no bip to ground (photo)
<RESISTOR>R8445</RESISTOR> - 5.11 V on both sides

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - No backlight - A stupid noob error
threads.message:
As per schematic, <CAPACITOR>C8441</CAPACITOR> and <RESISTOR>R8445</RESISTOR> have a common point.
Can you explain the voltage difference?
Check trace continuity.

BTW, stop to check voltage on both pads of a coil.
ALWAYS check the output, where the filter cap is connected.

those are filter caps right ? (photo)

threads.message:

The board pulling 20V / 0.41A on both ports and CPU getting hot, so I suppose it boots

The <CHIP>U8400</CHIP> does have VDDD - 5V but no FB on pin 21
I do get 13V on <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR> - pin 4 and 12.96V on pin 3

but nothing on Drain pins 1,2,5,6

is the <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR> dead ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - No backlight - A stupid noob error
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>BKLT_SD</SIGNAL> must go down, to open <TRANSISTOR>Q8400</TRANSISTOR>; don't touch it.

Do you get image for sure?
Is not possible, without L7210/20 voltage...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - No backlight - A stupid noob error
threads.message:
No image for sure in this case, nor USB activity; because of missing CPU core voltage.
Your board doesn't really boot, just stays on.

L7370 and L7730 voltage still present?

You can try known good BIOS, just in case.
But I doubt this helps...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - No backlight - A stupid noob error
threads.message:

and now it doesn't even turn on ?

couldn't it be a bad <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> or <CHIP>U7210</CHIP> ?

getting all those:

<SIGNAL>PM_EN_CPUVCC_R</SIGNAL> = 3.219V
<SIGNAL>CPU_VIDALERT_L</SIGNAL> = 111 mV
<SIGNAL>CPU_VCCST_PWRGD</SIGNAL> = 0.990V 
F7000 = 13V

I couldn't fry cpu just by doing some measurements, could I ? 

Also I'm getting exact same voltages as here [URL]https://boards.rossmanngroup.com/threads/<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1708</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>-dont-turn-on-after-taking-apart-<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.56105/[/URL]

But I couldn't find anything knocked off)))

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - No backlight - A stupid noob error
threads.message:
CPU core voltage is not controlled just by enable signal.
Part of CPU communicates with PCH through VID bus; both are in the same package on this board.
BIOS is also involved there.

CPU gets more volatges than core.
But is not normal to get hot when heatsink is installed, in such case.

This board should start with 1V, or bit higher on CPU core (L7210/20) and drops to 0.6V after 5-10s, when the board boots.
Do not expect iGPU voltage (L7410/20/30); it only appears under high load graphics.

Test the board alone, no SSD, LCD, TP/KB; nothing else than USB port.
Be sure to make good contacts when measure; you can use C10G0/H1 as test points, instead of L7210/20.

BTW, check L7900 and L8060 voltage too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - No backlight - A stupid noob error
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00875</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A - No backlight - A stupid noob error
threads.message:
Something happened with PCH/CPU.
Inspect under microscope that area (both sides), especially around <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>; does it get pins 41 & 42 voltage?
If cannot find anything, then very likely bad CPU.

You can try known good BIOS, as last step.
